subtitles.transcript: Representing the diversity of the kind of people of California should be part of the mission
of every university, right? And what’s hard, I think, in this day and age about being a public university
is we do take that, I think, very seriously, and yet we have some constraints policy-wise,
which prevent us from being able to do that to the extent —﻿ and they are constraints that our
private peers don’t have, right? Private universities aren’t under Prop. 209, right? So they can do
race-based recruiting, race-based admissions —﻿ they can take race into account in ways that we just can’t.
So it’s kind of an interesting position in that way, but I think that, you know,
clearly the private universities — Stanford, USC, if we’re talking about California, and the many, many others —
should share in the moral obligation to create, to serve students across the state
and across the nation in ways that supports diversity and that supports educating a kind of broad population.
